speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We’ll hear argument first this morning in case 08-1470, Berghuis v. Thompkins. Mr. Restuccia.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But he didn't -- he didn't waive them. And quite unlike Butler -- Butler, if I have it right, said, "I'll talk to you." So that was a statement --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that he was waiving the right to remain silent. He volunteered to talk. Here there was no such indication that there was a waiver of his right to remain silent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could you tell me without more detail, which is what the circuit court said, about what the limited responses -- I'm using your word -- were. How do we -- how can we imply waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Meaning if all he said was, yes, I want them in, that's much different than saying, if someone had asked him, do you want to leave, and he shakes his head no. The latter might imply to me that he waived, but the former certainly would be neutral.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That happened about 2 hours and 15 minutes into the exercise, didn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. So -- so what we have here is a course of conduct, 2 hours and 15 minutes of saying nothing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Would you say that that’s -- that's gone past the point where --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In Butler he said: I will talk to you, but I am not signing any forms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What they say is, “a course of conduct” -- we will not hold -- “This does not mean a defendant's silence, coupled with an understanding and a course of conduct indicating waiver, may never support a conclusion....”

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the prosecution's burden is great.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But going back to Justice Sotomayor's question, is there anything during the 2 hours and 15 minutes that could suggest a waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what do we do with our case law that says that you can't infer waiver simply from the confession?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I mean, we have said that. So that’s pretty clearly established statement --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- by the Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, I think certainly in -- in Butler, if someone in their confession says, I know I don't have to talk to you, but I want to, that that would be using those words.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So how can you say --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How can you say that an appeal to someone's religious position after 2 and a quarter hours is a voluntary waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We didn't say -- we don't have any decision that says the police are home free for 2 and a quarter hours. You said that that this was not lengthy interrogation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we -- we have no decision that says that the police, faced with a silent suspect, goes after that suspect, questioning him incessantly for 2 and -- 2 hours and 15 minutes, that that is not lengthy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He said "yeah," "no," and "I don't know."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wait. Do -- do we have any case that says that 2 and a quarter hours is too long?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that there can't be a waiver after 2 and a quarter hours?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And, therefore, there’s no clearly established Supreme Court law that 2 and a quarter hours is too long.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't that the name of the game here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is there a clearly established rule that in all of the circumstances of the case, we can find that there is coercion, time being one aspect of those circumstances?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And so that is a clearly established rule, and then it's a question whether 2 and a half, 3 and a half, 4 and a half suffices. -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But your -- your position is that if -- same facts, but it's 10 hours instead of 2 and a half, is that a closer case, at least? For --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And does that show that – that the circumstances are coercive, so that even if there were a waiver it would be --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The question, of course, is not whether we think 2 and a quarter hours under all the circumstances is -- is too long under our precedent. The question is, instead, whether it would be unreasonable for the State court to determine otherwise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought Miranda held that you can't question a person unless he waives his right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You can question him even after he -- it's clear that he hadn't waived his right. Is that -- that's Miranda? Or at least that's unclear? Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, I'm not talking about the waiver. I'm saying, imagine that it's clear that a person hasn't waived his right. Now let's suppose he says, "I do not waive my right." Okay? Now, is it clear law that once he says "I do not waive my right," the police cannot continue to question him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that clear law, yes or no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, yes. If that's clear law, would you say that at some point before the 2 hours and 15 minutes expires where they're continuously asking him questions and he says nothing, that it has become clear that he has not waived his right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: For the question is not this. The question is whether, after 2 hours and 15 minutes of silence, it is clear -- it's nothing about Supreme Court law. Supreme Court law is clear: You cannot question him after he makes clear he hasn't waived his right. So then the question becomes, is it reasonable for a State court to say -- after 2 hours and 15 minutes of asking questions and he says nothing, is it reasonable to hold that he has not -- conclude that he has not waived his rights? Is that the question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You’re saying there’s a difference between a waiver and a failure to assert?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You want to change the Miranda rule to say: Tell someone their rights, and unless they explicitly say "I don't want to talk to you," then they implicitly under virtually any circumstance haven't. That's what you believe the rule in Miranda and Butler and Davis sets forth?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: There wasn't -- there wasn’t silence in Butler. There was an express "I want to talk to you."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: My -- but we go back to the point you made earlier. Your position is the moment that someone confesses, that's an implicit waiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand how this person could just sit there for 2 hours and didn't want to be interrogated and doesn't say: You know, I don't want to answer your questions. He just sits there, and some questions he doesn't answer. And he does make a few comments, anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why shouldn't we have a rule which simply says if you don't want to be interrogated, all you have to say is "I don't want to answer your questions"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's nice and clear, wouldn't be any problem at all. That was never said here. He, in fact, submitted to having these questions asked of him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why should the police have to play this game of, you know, an hour and a half, 2 hours, 2 hours and 15 minutes, 5 hours, 7 hours? Why don't we have just a clear rule: You’re read your rights; if you don't want to be questioned all you have to say is: I don't want to be questioned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What would you do with Miranda's statement "But a valid waiver will not be presumed simply from the silence of the accused" -- I grant you, as modified in Butler to say that the State has a heavy burden of showing that the silence followed by a confession -- the State has a heavy burden of showing that that is an affirmative waiver. Now, those I think are the two statements of law, the third being that after, if there is no waiver, the police cannot continue to question. Now, I thought that was the clear law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I grant you, you might argue for a change in the law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is there any difference between -- between waiving your right and a failure to assert your right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is every failure to assert a waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about before that? What is happening before that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He hasn't asserted his right. I mean, he hasn't said I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He has done neither.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He has neither waived nor asserted.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Saharsky.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So do you read -- yes. So do you read Miranda as saying that there cannot be questioning unless there is a waiver? Then we'll go on to -- or do you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Okay, you do not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So are you going to go on -- because this is right where you are. Are you going to go on to say that, in the Miranda context, the failure to assert can -- can suffice to allow the questioning to proceed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But why isn't that language that you quote a negative inference that there must be a waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So there’s a difference between waiving at the time of the interrogation and then waiving it at the time of trial? I don't understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But in this case, it was the fact of the concession -- the confession that constituted the waiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I just want to make sure where we are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You’re not -- you’re conceding, it seems to me, that there must be a waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I just don't understand -- why -- why can't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: We have to guide the police.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why don't we tell the police, there must be a waiver before you can continue to interrogate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I don't know why you didn't answer Justice Stevens's questions by saying, Justice Stevens, I don't care about waiver. There was no -- there was no assertion of the right. But you’re not saying that. You are admitting there has to be a waiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why do you say it would change the police's behavior? Inbau and Reid and, you know, the -- the NAC -- the Defense Lawyers’ brief here is filled with quotations from typical police manuals, and they all seem to say things like you have to have at -- once the waiver is given, the police may proceed with interrogation. That seems to be what police today are instructed across the country. It says you cannot question people until he indicates after the warning is given a willingness to answer questions. That's the police manual. So why do you say this would extract a price on law enforcement when the typical police manuals seem to say what the Petitioner here is saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean the Respondent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Which -- which are the police manuals that go your way? Because I want to look at those, too.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, you’re saying there -- there’s a difference, I -- I assume, between not waiving and positively asserting your right not to be interrogated?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, if -- if he had -- here he simply refused to sign the -- the Miranda form, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which would have -- which would been the -- the waiver. And -- and you’re saying it's his later behavior that -- that showed that, in fact, he waived. What if instead of just refusing to sign, he had said, I do not want to be interrogated?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So -- so he has the right to terminate the whole thing by asserting his right. If he neither asserts the right nor grants the waiver, the police can continue to try to obtain a statement from him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But there also assumes there has to be a waiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Excuse me. As I read this transcript, the police's tactic, by their own statement, was to approach him and say: This is our evidence. Explain yourself -- that's the words the officer used -- but he's entitled to an alternative explanation. Tell us. What's clear is that at no point did he answer those questions, because nothing about the nods of the head or anything else showed a willingness to confess. And even in the responses he gave, he answered a series of questions with a “yes,” but not with an explanation, which was what was being requested. So my question is, how does one infer a voluntary statement from a situation in which someone's really not talking? I've never understood how a yes or a nod to questions that don't -- that's what the circuit said, to questions that we don't know what they were about -- do you want a mint or not, I don't even know that -- can reflect voluntariness? And I understand that in Butler when someone says I don't want to sign that, but I'm going to spill my guts now, and does, that's a course of conduct one could view as voluntary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Unless, I assume, that you -- you -- you acknowledge that if the interrogation had go on -- had gone on for so long that it had become coercive, then that -- that -- that last statement would not -- would not be a voluntary waiver.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Saharsky. Ms. Jacobs.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What happens when you read Butler?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Your argument is that you can infer waiver of the right to counsel from conduct, but you can't infer waiver of the right to remain silent from conduct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What's your best authority for that proposition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, basically what you’re saying is that if the defendant here had said at the beginning, I don't know whether I -- I want to talk to you or not, but I'm going to listen to your questions and I might answer some and I might answer others -- that would be a different case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And where is there -- what Supreme Court case establishes the distinction between those two situations clearly?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I'm not sure I really understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It depends on what you -- what you need to make "it," it depends on what "it" is. If -- if you mean the ultimate confession, I think I don't agree. Ultimately, if he confesses and hasn't been coerced, it's voluntary. But if by the "it" you mean to make the continuation of the interrogation voluntary, that's a different question. And I don't know that our cases establish that you cannot continue the interrogation until there has been a waiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But does that make it clear that -- that there has to be a waiver before the interrogation can continue? And if it does, how does it square with Butler?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They’re both under -- they’re both under Miranda. Both of those rights are Miranda rights.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I thought your answer was that there does not have to be a waiver before questioning can occur.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There must be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, Miranda does not say that. I mean, I think -- I think that Justice Scalia is right on that, that Miranda doesn't say you can't question him. The pages that you read to us say that if you have a lengthy questioning, then the fact that he then gives a statement cannot be taken as a -- cannot be admitted. That's -- that's what it seems to say on page 476 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in the absence of some special circumstance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Am I right? I mean Miranda does not explicitly say that you cannot continue questioning. Am I right about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm asking because I don't know. I didn't see it in the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, what if the person says: I'm not waiving, but I'm not saying that I will never waive. I’ll listen to your questions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: When he says --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- I'm not waiving?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I interrupt? Before I can understand your case, I would like to understand this hypothetical. If the person says: I'm not waiving, but I'm not telling you that I won't waive at some point in the future. I’ll listen to your questions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That's a waiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, he -- he didn't say anything. You -- I think you could say that his conduct implied the very kind of statement that Justice Alito suggested in his hypothetical: I'll listen to you guys for a while.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I -- just refresh my recollection. In the record in this case, do we know whether he said he understood his rights?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because that was present in Butler.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It was read to him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And they had him read a portion of the Miranda warning.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Huh?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I thought, in order to test his knowledge of English, they asked him to read one or two paragraphs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, they had him read --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So I -- boy, I -- what more do you need?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, he -- he’s listening when -- when they read it to him. He -- he -- he can read it himself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Maybe -- maybe he doesn't want to talk for the moment, but he does want to listen. I'm not sure you’re doing defendants a great -- a great favor. I mean, some of them might want to listen to -- to the police telling them, you know, by the way, your co-conspirator is singing like a bird and he's trying to pin it all on you, and maybe, you know, if -- if you don't want to get left holding the bag, maybe you’d better to talk to us and tell us what really happened. I'm not sure that -- that if I were there, even if I didn't want to talk right now, I might still want to listen, which is apparently what this -- what this person did. He could have said, I don't want to -- I don't want talk. And it -- and it would have ended. That would have been an assertion of his right. He didn't assert his right, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- he -- he sat there and listened. Now, maybe he wanted to find out what the police would have to say to him.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, we have it to the extent that he was told he had right to remain silent and he didn't say, I'm not going to talk to you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is it there any clearly established law the other way, which is the pertinent question?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We’re not talking -- we’re not talking about the Fifth Amendment right. We’re talking about the Miranda warnings. There’s no issue of voluntariness in this case. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: There’s no suggestion that there’s -- that the statements are not voluntary. The suggestion is that they may have violated Miranda.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if he said, do you want to remain silent?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And he doesn't answer either one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then you’re saying then that the defendant has to -- never has to invoke his right? That --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Was the Miranda warning adequate in this case? He got the four warnings, but then, unlike some police forms that then ask the defendant, do you waive your rights, this form never asked, did you waive your rights? It just said: Do you acknowledge that we have informed you of your rights?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You say you don't have to invoke your rights, but Butler also says that you can impliedly waive them. You don't have to expressly waive them.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right. So the question under AEDPA -- you agree there can be an implied waiver; that's what Butler says, right? So the question under AEDPA is whether the State court was unreasonable to determine that there was an implied waiver on these facts?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Maybe.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What are those?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, those facts are relevant only if we accept your -- your principal assertion, which is that you -- you don't have to invoke the right and interrogation must cease immediately. If we agree with that, then all of these facts become relevant. But if we think that, until you invoke the right, the police can continue to ask you questions and it's up to you to answer or not, then those facts are really not relevant at all, are they? I think that's true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It wasn't meant to be a trick question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: On your theory, those -- those factual things are irrelevant, whether --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Exactly, exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I must say I've never understood that to be the law, and I don't think it's generally understood to be the law, that unless you get a waiver right at the outset, you have to -- you have to terminate interrogation. I think there are a lot of police departments that don't -- I've never understood that to be the rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not saying it isn't a good rule. It may be a good rule. But the issue here is whether it is so clearly established that it was unreasonable for the State court to think otherwise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I like clear rules. Your rule is a clear one. Another clear one would be just the opposite of yours; that is, that interrogation can continue unless he asserts his right. That's another clear rule. We can go either way, and it will be clear.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could you tell me when the police have to stop? They read somebody their rights; the person says nothing. Are you saying at that point they have to stop?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But he doesn't answer. He just sits there --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- impassively.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Then they have to stop?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I don't see how you square that with Moseley.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And all he has to do is say: I don't want to talk to you. It's over.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't understand how they create the ambiguity.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I guess this gets back to a question I had earlier. I thought there was no dispute on this record that there was no involuntariness. We are talking about a violation of the technical, important but formal, Miranda requirements. This is not a case where the person says: My statements were involuntary.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's correct -- and that's where -- how I read Butler; you have to look at the circumstances. And you’re saying no, you don't look at any circumstances; they have got to ask the question and he has to waive.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The other circumstances are irrelevant. Well then, if yes, why are you talking to me about 2 hours 15 minutes, what they are doing? You say that circumstances don't matter.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That issue is not in this case, though.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: As I understand it, you've lost at every stage on the voluntariness and have not renewed that, correct? This is a Miranda case; it's not a Fifth Amendment case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Your argument would be the same if this was compressed to 45 minutes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Same result?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: 30 minutes?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: One? I mean, that's -- I don't want to piggyback off Justice Kennedy's point, but that's the whole point, is you do not look at any of those circumstances, you say. Before they can say anything more, they have to get a waiver. So it's 30 seconds if they go on, before they -- if they sit there for how long before -- how long do they have to ask, do you want to waive?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could -- could you describe a situation where you think there would be an implied waiver?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I thought that -- that doesn't sound implied. That sounds express to me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wait. Excuse me. A waiver of what? I thought the Chief Justice was talking about a waiver of your right to remain silent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That wasn't a waiver --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- of his right to remain silent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm willing to talk to you, I'm willing to listen to you. It seems to me you’re confusing a -- a waiver of -- of the right to remain silent with a waiver of the right not to be interrogated, which is the right that you are asserting here, a right not to be interrogated, unless going in you say, I waive my right to remain silent. That's -- that's the new right that you are asserting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A right not to be interrogated.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay. So what -- what is an implied waiver case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's right. Now, getting back to Ms. Saharsky's point, she said if you prevail, you have to overrule Butler. And it seems to me that that's the point we're at.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, there's -- so, there's no implied waiver with respect to the right to remain silent?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Restuccia, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I have to say that -- page 475 and 476, particularly, of Miranda do talk in terms of a -- of a waiver. Did -- are there -- did the subsequent cases indicate an articulation of that view that’s closer to your position?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What page is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, why doesn’t it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But I don't think that was the question. The question, at least as I understood it, is that Miranda says you cannot admit a confession into evidence unless he has first waived it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then it says, clearly, that even if the police and the prosecution testify he did waive it, even if they say he did, explicitly, still, if there's a long questioning, even then, the court should be very careful about admitting it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And doesn't it flow from that a fortiori that if he doesn’t admit it and all there is, is the long questioning that, there has been no waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He answered three questions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. One, do you believe in God? Yes. Two, do you pray to God? Yes. Three, have you asked God for forgiveness for shooting the boy? Yes. Okay. So, where -- where did he waive it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, in this case, after 2 hours and 15 minutes when he gave the answers I just said, when did he waive his Miranda rights?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, I think any then -- then Miranda is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It says you can't admit the stuff after a long questioning unless he waives. Obviously, he says something or there would be nothing to admit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask, can you go back to page 14 in your reply brief? "Once warnings have been given, the subsequent procedure is clear. If the individual indicates in any manner, at any time prior to or during questioning, that he wishes to remain silent, the interrogation must cease."

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So the question is whether during those two hours by not answering a -- a number of questions, did he indicate in any way that he wished to remain silent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Then it says that any -- in any manner that he wished to remain silent. And until the 2 hours and a half later when he did answer the three questions, that's pretty -- it's at least arguable that his silence indicated he wished to remain silent.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The case is submitted.
